title: List of national parks of Denmark
text:
There are six national parks in the <a href="Denmark">Kingdom of Denmark</a>; five in Denmark proper and one in <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>.
The first national park in Denmark proper was <a href="Thy%20National%20Park">Thy National Park</a> (), created in 2008. It is located in <a href="Thisted%20Municipality">Thisted Municipality</a>, <a href="Region%20Nordjylland">Nordjylland</a>. The park is a narrow stretch of land along the <a href="North%20Jutlandic%20Island">North Jutlandic Island</a>'s west coast from <a href="Hanstholm">Hanstholm</a> southward to <a href="Agger%20Tange">Agger Tange</a>, excluding Hanstholm, Klitmøller, Nørre Vorupør, Stenbjerg and Agger. Thy National Park is named after <a href="Thy%20%28district%29">Thy</a>, an area that includes not only today's national park but also adjacent land further east. The park has dunes, <a href="Heath%20%28habitat%29">heath</a>, forests and grassland and also covers several small lakes and a small part of the <a href="Limfjord">Limfjord</a>, which is the fjord that separates the North Jutlandic Island from the <a href="Jutland%20Peninsula">Cimbrian Peninsula</a>.
In August 2009, the second national park <a href="Mols%20Bjerge%20National%20Park">Mols Bjerge National Park</a> was inaugurated, followed by <a href="Wadden%20Sea%20National%20Park%2C%20Denmark">Wadden Sea National Park</a> in October 2010, and <a href="Land%20of%20the%20Scylding%20National%20Park">Land of the Scylding National Park</a> in 2015. Two additional areas in mainland Denmark were proposed in 2008 and 2009 to become national parks. One of these plans, Skjern Å Nationalpark (after the <a href="Skjern%20River">river of the same name</a>), was abandoned in 2012, but it was restarted in 2018 and is ongoing. The other, <a href="Kongernes%20Nordsj%C3%A6lland%20National%20Park">Kongernes Nordsjælland National Park</a>, was inaugurated in 2018.
Greenland has had its own national park since 1974. The <a href="Northeast%20Greenland%20National%20Park">Northeast Greenland National Park</a> stretches across three fifths of the northern parts of <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>'s east coast and, since its expansion in 1988, two thirds of the eastern parts of Greenland's north coast. Bounded by the coasts, the park covers the island's entire north-eastern quarter, all of which is almost uninhabited. 
Like Greenland, the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a> forms another <a href="Autonomous%20administrative%20division">autonomous region</a> of the Kingdom of Denmark, but contains no national parks.
